Award.AwardTitle: Informal science learning at biological field stations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal Science Learning program funds innovative research, approaches and resources for use in a variety of settings. This Exploratory Pathways project brings together scientists and science curriculum experts with field station leaders to study informal science learning at biological field stations. The objective is to understand and evaluate the unique qualities of field stations as centers of informal and enduring science learning for the non-science community. There are over 400 field stations and represent a science communication mechanism that if available to most US citizens. This project is a collaboration between Texas A&M University and Colorado State University.

Field stations typically engage in informal science learning. While there are great examples of informal learning through outreach activities at field stations, little is known about what is happening in the aggregate at these establishments. This project documents the outreach work of field stations and explores the connections between how the outreach activities engage learners, incorporate science topics, and address science learning. By creating an Outreach Ontology, a multidimensional framework around the outreach activities, this work provides a valuable resource and reference to informal science researchers who seek to understand what informal learning projects are undertaken at field stations, and how these activities fit into the broader context of informal science learning. This project will help field stations collaborate on improving informal STEM learning activities by bringing them together to discuss their efforts and by developing a publicly available, searchable database detailing their activities. A particular benefit to advancing informal STEM learning by investigating field stations is the broad range of people and communities that are involved with and affected by field station outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Exploratory Pathways project had four major goals: 1) identify the biological field stations (BFSs) in the United States that are engaging the general public with outreach programming, 2) survey these BFSs about their outreach programming to profile how they engage learners and incorporate science learning, 3) create a conceptual model of informal STEM learning at BFSs that maps the approaches for learner engagement and the six strands of science learning onto place-based activities offered at BFSs, and 4) develop resources for BFSs, the informal learning community, and other practitioners to help them network and share ideas to improve outreach efforts.

Intellectual merit: To achieve these goals, this project developed a conceptual framework for advancing informal STEM learning at field stations (Struminger et al. 2018) and documented the outreach work of BFSs through an outreach survey. The Outreach Framework centers the place-based activities field stations offer the public, and relates those activities to (a) learner engagement (e.g., with experiential learning methods), (b) STEM content, and (c) science learning (e.g., expose learners to scientific processes), to (d) achieve desired learning outcomes for participants. The project advances and refines learning theories as they relate to informal STEM education at biological field stations by providing an underserved professional audience (informal educators and practitioners at field stations) with new perspectives on how to apply these theories. With an online survey, we collected data on 396 outreach programs from 223 biological field stations (BFSs). Survey results are presented in forthcoming articles that highlight the design and delivery of outreach programs for the general public and show BFSs as providers of informal STEM education that promote science literacy. Our research also resulted in a published article that illustrates the geographic locations of field stations and marine laboratories, and their unique position to help reach populations underrepresented in the sciences when compared to the locations of most other types of informal learning institutions (Short et al. 2020).

Broader impacts: Many of the broader impacts of this project are intricately linked with the intellectual merit. Understanding the places and qualities of informal STEM learning at biological field stations allows us to pinpoint successful programming and to identify opportunities for new programming?especially for groups not well represented in STEM careers. The Outreach Framework provides a way to think through how to evaluate informal learning programs that could be used across a broader suite of informal learning institution types. In addition to the broader impacts that emerged from our research findings, this project actively supported diversity in STEM. A male graduate student with Latino heritage, a female graduate student who is a first-generation college student from a low-income family and has a disability, a non-traditional female graduate student, and three early career female assistant professors were supported by this project. A pilot wiki aligns stations? programs with the Outreach Framework and profiles programs so the public, field stations, and the broader informal STEM learning community can see what opportunities exist at biological field stations. In addition to scholarly publications and our project web site <https://fieldstationoutreach.info>, we led 17 workshops, symposia and conference presentations at national and international venues to disseminate our research findings and help field station personnel apply principles of informal STEM education to public outreach events.
